default: One {@filter simple weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon} of your choice
One set of {@item artisan's tools|PHB|tools} with which you are proficient
(a) a {@item explorer's pack|phb}, (b) a {@item diplomat's pack|PHB}, (c) a {@item scholar's pack|PHB}, or (d) a {@item burglar's pack|PHB}

classFeatures.name: From Common Birth
entries: Starting at 1st level, you gain appreciation for the struggles of the common man. Those who look at you recognize you as a steady, down-to-earth person-the dirt under your fingernails or the weary gaze in your eyes speak volumes. You gain the following benefits, depending on who you interact with:

items: You have advantage on Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) rolls made when interacting with everyday workers. Common folk look out for each other; bartenders become more likely to share scandalous gossip with you, farmers are more likely to shelter you in their homes for a night, and common townsfolk are more likely to warn you when trouble is afoot.
You have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) rolls made towards any merchants or swindlers who may be trying to take advantage of your hard-earned money.

You have advantage on Charisma ({@skill Deception}) rolls made when you are attempting to convince any sort of authority that you didn't do something. Arrogant nobility is biased to assume that all common people are lazy and unremarkable, and they will naturally disbelieve you if you claim any great accomplishment.

entries: In addition, you understand trader talk–a heavy mix of dialect and jargon that is popular among tradesmen and travelers. Trader talk sounds rough and uses a great deal of obscure slang (often referring to mundane objects through weird names) which allows traders to recognize and communicate exclusively between themselves. It varies greatly depending on location and dialect, but folk heroes know how to translate heavily-accented voices and you can decipher any profession-specific slang.

Merchants will often treat anybody who understands trader talk differently; unscrupulous merchants that might otherwise attempt to take advantage will do not do so, while other tradesmen may even offer favors or advice.

classFeatures.name: Trusty Weapon
entries: Starting at 1st level, you make do with what you've got and get the job done. You obtain your own personal trusty weapon. This may not be the fanciest weapon, but it's yours–and you know how to use it. During a long rest, you can convert a set of artisan's tools with which you have proficiency to make your trusty weapon. You decide the shape, size and damage type of your trusty weapon as you are creating it, but it must be either:

items: a one-handed melee weapon with the light and finesse properties that deals {@dice 1d6} bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage (your choice).
a two-handed melee weapon with the reach property that deals {@dice 1d10} bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage (your choice).
a sling with range of 30/120 that deals {@dice 1d6} bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage (your choice).

entries: While you wield your trusty weapon, you apply the following features to it:

items: When making attack rolls, rather than adding your proficiency bonus + your Strength or Dexterity modifier, you may instead add your 2 × your proficiency bonus to the attack roll.
When dealing damage, rather than adding your Strength or Dexterity modifier, you may instead add your proficiency bonus to the damage roll.

entries: Only you can use your trusty weapon in this way–to anybody else, it is considered a normal improvised weapon. You can only possess one trusty weapon at any time, and if you lose it, you may craft a replacement out of another set of artisan's tools.

classFeatures.name: Livelihood
entries: Folk Heroes come from many different upbringings. Your livelihood determines your job, your experiences, and forms a major part of your character.
Your Livelihood grant additional class features at 1st, 5th, 9th and 14th level.

classFeatures.name: Folk Hero? No, Just a Commoner
entries: Coming from a life of common work has left you able to adeptly disguise your presence by masquerading as a commoner. Starting at 2nd level, whenever you would be reduced to 0 hit points by a creature, you instead drop to 1 hit point fall {@condition prone}.

Any hostile creatures in the area must make a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check with DC equal to 10 + (2 × your proficiency bonus). On a failure, that creature assumes you are dead and moves onto a new target. This feature lasts until you move or take an action, at which point your guise as a mere commoner will be revealed.
Once you use this feature, you cannot use it again until you finish a long rest.

classFeatures.name: Helping Hand
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can use the {@action Help} action as a bonus action.

classFeatures.name: Rough and Ready
entries: When faced with an unfamiliar challenge, you roll your sleeves up and get it done. Starting at 3rd level, you can spend ten minutes practicing using a set of tools and gain a temporary proficiency bonus. This proficiency lasts until your finish a long rest, and you can only have one at a time.

This proficiency bonus can be applied towards any tool, mount, or vehicle, so you long as you have an object in hand that you can use to practice. You cannot gain skill proficiencies using this feature.
Starting 6th level, you double your proficiency with any tool, mount, or vehicle proficiency you gain using this feature.

classFeatures.name: Learn Feat
entries: When you reach 4th level, you learn one feat of your choice.

entries.name: Why No Ability Score Improvements?
entries: Learning a feat better suits the folk hero's theme rather than taking Ability Score Improvements. With this class, it is better to have a variety of different skills, rather than trying to master any singular ability.

classFeatures.name: Assisting the Cause
entries: You may not be as crazy as the adventurers around you, but you can assist regardless of the circumstances. Starting at 5th level, whenever you assist an ally using the {@action Help} action, that ally adds your proficiency bonus to their melee and ranged weapon attack rolls.

In addition, if an ally you assist using the {@action Help} action successfully hits a creature on their turn, you can follow up with your own barrage. You make one attack on the same creature at the end of your ally's turn. If your ally hit multiple creatures, you choose one to attack.

classFeatures.name: Livelihood Feature
entries: At 5th level, you gain a feature granted by your Folk Hero Livelihood.

classFeatures.name: Weapon of a Hero
entries: Starting at 6th level, your trusty weapon begins to mold into a weapon fitting of a prospective hero. Your trusty weapon is now considered magical for the purpose of overcoming immunity and resistance to non-magical attacks and damage.
In addition, your familiarity with your trusty weapon allows you to use it in new and interesting ways. When you craft a trusty weapon, select one of the following Fits to apply:

entries.name: Grappling Fit
entries: {@bold Prerequisites:} a one-handed or two-handed melee trusty weapon.

With this Fit, your weapon becomes more than just a weapon–it's an extension of your arm. When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can use a bonus action to attempt to grapple the target. You do not need a free hand to grapple, as you use your weapon to hook and grab the target. You can still attack a creature while grappling them this way. Add your proficiency bonus to any Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check you make in order to grapple a creature with this Fit.

entries.name: Crippling Fit
entries: {@bold Prerequisites:} a one-handed or two-handed melee trusty weapon.

With this Fit, you go for the hamstrings. When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, the target must succed on a Dexterity saving throw with a DC equal to 8 + (2 × your proficiency bonus). On a failed save, that creature's movement speed is reduced by half until the end of its next turn. Regardless of whether creature passes or fails the save, you do not provoke opportunity attacks from them until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Knockback Fit
entries: {@bold Prerequisites:} a sling trusty weapon.

With this Fit, projectiles from your sling have significant stopping power. When you hit a creature with a ranged weapon attack, you can forcefully knock a Huge or smaller creature back up to 5 feet. Small or smaller creatures are instead thrown back up to 10 feet.

entries.name: First Strike Fit
entries: {@bold Prerequisites:} a sling trusty weapon.

With this Fit, projectiles from your sling fire unconventionally, taking most creatures by complete surprise. On your first attack against a creature in combat, you deal an additional {@dice 1d4} damage of your sling's type. This effect can be triggered on different creatures, but only on your first attack. Regardless of whether you miss.

classFeatures.name: Close Shave
entries: At 7th level, you've begun to get a hang of this adventuring business. Whenever an effect or attack would inflict damage equal to more than half your current hit points, you can use a reaction to cause it to deal only half your current hit points instead (rounded up).
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and regain all expended uses on a long rest.

classFeatures.name: Learn Feat
entries: When you reach 8th level, you learn one feat of your choice.

classFeatures.name: Livelihood Feature
entries: At 9th level, you gain a feature granted by your Folk Hero Livelihood.

classFeatures.name: Teamwork Gets It Done
entries: You aren't the sort to fight alone. Starting at 10th level, you've learned how to coordinate with others, becoming the glue that holds a group together. At the start of a quest or upon completing a long rest, you can pick up to two willing allies and form a team. Until your next long rest, so long as those allies remain within both earshot and line of sight of you and each other, then the team has the following benefits:

items: When any member of the team makes an ability check, they may choose to use the relevant ability modifier of another member instead of their own.
If one member of the team is within 5 feet of a hostile creature, all other members of may attack that creature with advantage.

When you use the {@action Help} action to assist an ally in attacking a hostile creature, any benefits of your Help action apply equally to all members of your team. If multiple allies hit a creature, you may make multiple attacks with Assisting the Cause. You do not need to target a hostile creature to grant this benefit.

entries: Starting at 15th level, the amount of allies that can be members of your team increase to three.

classFeatures.name: I Can't Believe That Worked!
entries: Starting at 11th level, whenever you score a critical hit against a creature using the {@action Attack} action, you can make a second attack immediately after. In addition, the creature must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to 8 + (2 × your proficiency bonus) or become {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. You can only stun a creature this way once per round.

classFeatures.name: Learn Feat
entries: When you reach 12th level, you learn one feat of your choice.

classFeatures.name: Watch Out!
entries: By 13th level, others in your party have begun to look to you to decide whether they should run. As a reaction, you can use your Close Shave feature on other members of your team. You can only use Close Shave this way a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and regain all expended uses on a long rest.

classFeatures.name: Livelihood Feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Folk Hero Livelihood.

classFeatures.name: Learn Feat
entries: When you reach 16th level, you learn one feat of your choice.

classFeatures.name: Look At Us Go!
entries: Starting 17th level, your I Can't Believe That Worked! feature applies to all members of your current team. Each member of your team other than you can only activate this feature once per round.

classFeatures.name: Learn Feat
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can learn one feat of your choice.

classFeatures.name: Learn It From Me
entries: Starting at 20th level, you've become a true hero. A bastion and inspiration to your allies. A globe-trotting adventurer to which all herald your name. You can share the benefits of one feat that you know with all members of your current team.

subclassFeatures.name: Farmer Livelihood
entries: A farmer–could there be any more noble of a profession? Well, yes, probably–but, even so, those people would all starve if you didn't do what you do. Farmers are hardy folk. They work the fields, you herd livestock, they do all of the dirty, back-breaking work just so others can eat. That type labor builds muscle, and responsibility.

entries.name: Skills of the Field
entries: Starting at 1st level, you gain the following:

items: Skill proficiency in two of the following: {@skill Survival}, {@skill Nature} or {@skill Animal Handling}. If you already have proficiency in that skill, gain expertise.
Tool proficiency with {@item herbalism kit|phb}. If you already have this tool proficiency, pick another of your choice.
Proficiency with Strength saving throws.

entries: {@note {@b This feature applies only if folk hero is your first class (i.e. you do not gain this feature if you choose this subclass as a multiclass).}}

entries.name: Long Hours, Heavy Work
entries: Also starting at 1st level, you grow accustomed to moving heavy loads. You count as one size larger when it comes to determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can pull, push, or drag.

In addition, you can use an action to temporarily remove a single point of exhaustion, the effects of which will return at the end of your next short rest.  Once you use this feature, you cannot use it again until you finish a long rest..

subclassFeatures.name: Farmer's Grit
entries: At 5th level, whether you’re up against a stubborn bull or ploughing tough earth, you know how to grit your teeth and force your way through. As a bonus action, you receive the following benefits:

items: You gain resistance to slashing, bludgeoning, and piercing damage.
You gain advantage on all checks made to grapple.
You gain temporary hit points equal to your Folk Hero level.
Your Strength ability score modifier increases by +2. Your Strength ability score does not increase with this feature.

entries: These effect last for five minutes. Once you use this feature, you cannot use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeatures.name: Homecooked Grub
entries: A good meal braces you for the day. During a short rest, you can use the ingredients of mother nature to cook a hale-and-hearty meal for you and your companions. You and up to five fo your companions gain temporary hit points equal to {dice 3d6} + your Folk Hero level. Once you use this feature, you cannot use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeatures.name: All Together Now
entries: Starting at 14th level, you weather any hardships side-by-side with your fellow farmhands. When you use your Farmer's Grit feature, your whole team gains resistance to slashing, bludgeoning and piercing damage.

subclassFeatures.name: Merchant Livelihood
entries: You are a merchant at heart. This whole adventuring business is a neat side hustle, but a merchant's true purpose is to buy, sell and make a profit. Merchants are clever and persuasive, they survive by bartering with others, finding the right goods for the job, and–most importantly–by earning money.

entries.name: Skills of the Trade
entries: Starting at 1st level, you gain the following:

items: Skill proficiency in two of the following: {@skill Insight}, {@skill Deception} or {@skill Persuasion}. If you already have proficiency in that skill, gain expertise.
Tool proficiency with {@item forgery kit|PHB}. If you already have this tool proficiency, pick another of your choice.
Proficiency with Charisma saving throws.

entries: {@note {@b Note: This feature applies only if folk hero is your first class (i.e. you do not gain this feature if you choose this subclass as a multiclass).}}

entries.name: Coin Wherever You Go
entries: Also at 1st level, you're in the habit of picking up bits and pieces during your travels. As an action, you can attempt to loot a body within reach of you. After scravenging through the creature's pockets for one minute, you produce an amount of gold pieces equal to 2 × your Folk Hero level. You cannot scravenge a creature you've already looted. You can scravenge through a creature's pockets a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and regain all expended uses on a long rest.
In addition, you know the average selling prices of any items you have encountered before, and you instantly become aware if another merchant is overcharging you for familiar goods.

subclassFeatures.name: Everything's For Sale
entries: At 5th level, you understand that money dictates all. This has the following benefits:

items: Any {@skill Persuasion} roll less than a 9 is considered a 9 instead.
You gain advantage on any Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) checks made to bribe.

entries: Additionally, If combat begins against any enemy that has reason to care about such things (e.g. if bandits ambushes you, or if you encounter goblins hoarding gold) then you can use an action to interrupt initiative order and offer up payment instead of fighting. The DM will inform you immediately whether or not your attempt was successful. If successful, the enemies will name a price–the exact sum dependent on the situation–and if you can pay that price then those enemy will abandon hostilities so long as your party does the same.

subclassFeatures.name: Nothing But the Best
entries: You piece together bits and pieces, and slowly but surely enough your wares expand. At 9th level, you acquire an uncommon magic item of your choice–preferably an item related to your backstory or journey, and must be from a source book allowed in the SRP (PHB, DMG, XGE, ERLW, TCE) or the Guild Shop.
At 13th level, you acquire an additional rare magic item through this feature. At 17th level, you acquire an additional very rare magic item.

subclassFeatures.name: Company Trading
entries: By 14th level, you've learned how to work effectively in more ways than just combat. You gain the following benefits:

items: At the beginning of each month, you gain an additional week of downtime.
You and other members of your team receive a 25% discount when purchasing mundane goods from merchants. This feature does not benefit purchases made using downtime.

A member of your team can pass a magic item to a different member, causing the magic item to instantly attune to its new wielder. When attuning to the new item, the member receiving the item can choose to immediately unattune to one of their own magic items before attuning to the new item. Each member of the team can only gain the benefits of this feature once per long rest.

subclassFeatures.name: Receptionist Livelihood
entries: Receptionists may appear humble and unassuming, but they are not to be underestimated. A receptionist may work as a teller in a bank, or as a lord's scribe, or as a receptionist in the Adventurer's Association–but the purpose is the same. They run the ship. They deal with people, paperwork and more paperwork. The receptionists see everything that ever happens more clearly than the people in charge, and nothing gets done unless the receptionist does it.

entries.name: Skills of the Office
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you gain the following:

items: Skill proficiency in two of the following: {@skill Arcana}, {@skill Investigation} or {@skill History}. If you already have proficiency in that skill, gain expertise.
Tool proficiency with {@item calligrapher's supplies|PHB}. If you already have this tool proficiency, pick another of your choice.
Proficiency with Intelligence saving throws.

entries: {@note {@b This feature applies only if folk hero is your first class (i.e. you do not gain this feature if you choose this subclass as a multiclass).}}

entries.name: Exhaustive Attentiveness
entries: Also at 1st level, if you spend at least one minute observing or interacting with another creature outside of combat, you can ascertain certain surrounding it and the threat it poses. Ask your DM for one piece of information from the following list. If your DM cannot discern a proper response, you may select another option from the list below:

items: The creature's threat level, determined by a numerical value referred to as CR or level.

The creature's level of fortitude, represented by a numerical scale called hit points. You learn whether the creature has less than your current hit points, more than your current hit points, or more than double your current hit points.
The creature's designated area of expertise, often determined using a list of various professions called classes.
The arcana the creature was born under, if any.
Any resistances or immunities that the creature possesses.

entries: You can use this feature any number of times, but you can only discern one piece of information about a specific creature per day.

subclassFeatures.name: Magic of a Receptionist
entries: You know, magic isn't really that difficult. Wizards overcomplicate everything. At the end of the day, being a Wizard is just reading from a fancy book. You know how to read.

Starting at 5th level, you gain the ability to write up spells into your own spellbook called the Receptionist's Binder. You do not possess any spell slots, but you can cast spells as a ritual while your binder is in hand. Choose {@filter two|spells|level=1|level=2|components & miscellaneous= Ritual} 1st level spells and one 2nd level spell that both contain the ritual tag from any spell list. Your spellcasting ability for these spells is Intelligence.

If you come across a spell in written form during your travels, you can attempt to add them into your binder. The spell's level can be no higher than half your level (rounded up), and it must have the ritual tag. The process of copying the spell into your binder requires two hours and 50 gold per level of the spell

In addition, you can use the {@action Help} action to assist spellcasters with the casting of their spells. While you are assisting an ally this way, they add your Intelligence modifier to their spell attack rolls. Finally, you can use the {@action Help} action on an ally within 10 feet of you.

subclassFeatures.name: Arcane Receptionist
entries: By 9th level, you've practically become a mage yourself! Sort of. You still need that trusty binder of yours. You instantly acquire {@filter two|spells|level=1|level=2|level=3|level=4|components & miscmiscellaneous=ritual} ritual spells from any spell list, up to 4th-level. At 13th level, you acquire an additional {@filter two|spells|level=1|level=2|level=3|level=4|level=5|components & miscmiscellaneous=ritual} ritual spells from any spell list, up to 5th-level. At 17th level, you acquire an additional {@filter two|spells|level=1|level=2|level=3|level=4|level=5|level=6|components & miscmiscellaneous=ritual} ritual spells from any spell list, up to 6th-level.

Also starting at 9th level, although you tend to use complicated language when jotting down notes, you've at least learned to simplify your speech when attempting to compare them. You can now share your binder with other spellcasters like a spellbook. Likewise, you can copy spells from an ally's spellbook into your binder for later use.

You cannot use any spells you copy externally. However, you gain the ability to use spells copied within your binder in a much more devious way. You can lend your binder to a spellcaster, allowing them to expend one of their own spell slots in order to cast a spell from your binder (even if that spell is not on their spell list). In order to carry out this special casting, you must be performing the {@action Help} action on them.
Finally, the time required for you to cast ritual spells is halved.

subclassFeatures.name: Master Scribe
entries: At 14th level, you apply your keen knowledge in order to assist your team. Whenever a member of your team casts a spell while you are supporting them with the {@action Help} action, they receive the following benefits:

items: You can take over both the verbal and somatic components of the spell.

Your contribution reinforces the spell as you quickly draw up components from your binder to fortify the casting. You increase the level of your ally's spell by a single level (to a maximum of 9th). You can use this feature a number of times equal to twice your Intelligence modifier, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeatures.name: Vagabond Livelihood
entries: The life of a vagabond is a rough one. Vagabonds are homeless, constantly on the move, and always restless. Guardsmen will often chase vagabibds out of town, or monsters might ambush them on the road–yet vagabonds are survivors. Sometimes they take on odd jobs, sometimes they will beg on corners, and sometimes they will even resort to crime–but they will do whatever it takes. Vagabonds are self-reliant, and look out for themselves above all others.

entries.name: Skills of the Road
entries: Starting at 1st level, you gain the following:

items: Skill proficiency in two of the following: {@skill Survival}, {@skill Stealth} or {@skill Sleight of Hand}. If you already have proficiency in that skill, gain expertise.
Tool proficiency with {@item thieves' tools|PHB}. If you already have this tool proficiency, pick another of your choice.
Proficiency with Dexterity saving throws.

entries: {@note {@b This feature applies only if folk hero is your first class (i.e. you do not gain this feature if you choose this subclass as a multiclass).}}

entries.name: Didn't Do Nothin'
entries: People look down on beggars. For you, that's one of the world's few gifts. Starting at 1st level, if you remain motionless in a crowd or dimly-lit environment, you are considered to be {@condition invisible}. This effect ends the moment you move or perform any actions that involve movement, such as the {@action Attack} action.

subclassFeatures.name: Wasn't Me
entries: Starting at 5th level, you have perfected the art of staying safe by blaming others. Immediately after making an attack roll against an hostile creature while you are within 5 feet of an allied creature, you can make a Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check against that hostile creature's passive perception. On a success, the hostile creature believes the attack came from your ally, rather than yourself.

Until the end of your turn, if you would provoke an opportunity attack from that creature, the attack is instead made at your ally. If you successfully pin the blame on an allied creature and end your turn at least 10 feet away from any hostile creatures, you become {@condition invisible} under the same restrictions as your Didn't Do Nothin' feature.

subclassFeatures.name: Stick 'Em in the Back
entries: Starting at 9th level, you know how to exploit any opportunity. When you make a successful attack against a creature with advantage, you deal an additional {@dice 2d6} damage of the weapon's primary damage type. You can only apply this bonus once each round.
This extra damage becomes {@dice 3d6} at 13th level and {@dice 4d6} at 17th level.

subclassFeatures.name: Go For the Other Guy
entries: The best thing about being a part of a team is that the other people can serve as distractions. Starting at 14th level, you can slip away and divert an opponent's attention away from yourself and to somebody else. If a creature is about to target you with an attack, you can use your reaction to roll a {@dice d4}.

items: On a roll of 1, the creature will continue to target you.
On any other result, the creature will ignore you and move onto a randomly selected member of your team within range.

entries: Until the end of their next turn, the creature you used this feature on must focus all its attacks on the team member determined by the {@dice d4} roll. You can use this feature twice, and regain all expended uses on a short or long rest.

subclassFeatures.name: Thug Livelihood
entries: Thugs are a common sight wherever you go. A thug might be a bouncer, a bandit, a guard or a pit-fighter–or just anyone who is mean enough. It's a very simple profession; thugs know how to hit things, and they earn money with their fists. They are people with bad reputations and a propensity towards violence.

In truth, thugs are not actually good at combat. They know nothing about the subtler aspects of fighting–but that hasn't stopped them yet. Thugs deal damage and little else. They are good at knocking the other guy down.

entries.name: Skills of the Mob
entries: Starting at 1st level, you gain the following:

items: Skill proficiency in one of the following: {@skill Athletics} or {@skill Intimidation}. If you already have proficiency in that skill, gain expertise.
Proficiency with heavy armor.
Proficiency with Strength saving throws.

entries: {@note {@b This feature applies only if folk hero is your first class (i.e. you do not gain this feature if you choose this subclass as a multiclass).}}

entries.name: Stomp 'Em Good
entries: There's nothing sweeter than watching the bodies drop, and you savor that moment whenever you see it. Starting at 1st level, whenever you or an ally you're assisting with the {@action Help} action reduce a hostile creature to 0 hit points, or when a creature you are grappling is reduced to 0 hit points by an ally, you can move up to half your movement speed and make a single grapple attack against a different target.

subclassFeatures.name: Brutish Moxie
entries: Okay, so you aren't the most skillful fighter. That's fine. What you don't have in skill, you more than make up for your delivering in hurt. Although to be fair, sometimes the one being hurt is you.

Starting at 5th level, whenever you make a melee weapon attack against a creature, you may choose to turn it into a wild, reckless assault on both the body and the ears. On a successful hit, you add your Strength modifier to the bonus of either the attack or damage roll (your choice) and take {@dice 1d4} bludgeoning damage as you crash into your opponent.
You can choose to use this feature after you make an attack roll, but before the DM determines whether the attack roll succeeds or fails.

subclassFeatures.name: Headbutt
entries: Your teachers once told you that you need to use your head more–this is what they meant, right?

Starting at 9th level, through trial and error, you've figured out how to create the best bullet in the world: your body, sprawling towards your opponents head-first. When you make an attack roll against a creature, instead of dealing the damage of your weapon, you can instead choose to deal {@dice 1d8} bludgeoning damage as your head collides straight into their body.

On a successful hit, both you and the creature must make a contested Constitution check. The creature who fails this contested check falls {@condition unconscious} until the end of their next turn. A creature two or more sizes larger than you automatically succeeds this check.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier (minimum of once), and regain all expended uses on a long rest.

subclassFeatures.name: Mob Rule #1
entries: Never fight alone. Overpower your enemies with numbers on your side. By the way: there's only one rule.

Starting at 14th level, you've mastered the sacred art of "ganging up on the other guy". When you and at least two other members of your team are within 5 feet of a creature, you all gain a +3 bonus on attack rolls against that creature.

subclassFeatures.name: Inkeep Livelihood
entries: Innkeeping is a profession for the empathetic and protective. Perhaps they can't fight that all well, but they can serve ale and cook up one hell of a stew. In many ways, innkeepers are a precious commodity–after all, when it's pouring down with rain and the party is trapped inside a stinky goblin's cave, most adventurers tend to wish if only there was a good innkeeper about.

Innkeepers are those with experience running inn or tavern, they don't tolerate nonsense and they know how to look after their patrons. Sometimes, there is no better friend to have: they care for others, they feed the party and get people up on their feet.

entries.name: Skills of the House
entries: Starting at 1st level, you gain the following:

items: Skill proficiency in two of the following: {@skill Insight}, {@skill Persuasion}, or {@skill Medicine}. If you already have proficiency in that skill, gain expertise.
Tool proficiency with {@item cook's utensils|PHB}. If you already have this tool proficiency, pick another of your choice.
Proficiency with Wisdom saving throws.

entries: {@note {@b This feature applies only if folk hero is your first class (i.e. you do not gain this feature if you choose this subclass as a multiclass).}}

entries.name: Quick Recovery
entries: Starting at 1st level, you know how to bring drunkards back to their feet after they fall down. When an allied creature drops to 0 hit points and begins to make death saving throws, you can use an action to return them to 1 hit point. Once you use this feature, you cannot use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeatures.name: Hospitable Host
entries: You're good with people; you can befriend strangers, and you've learned how to de-escalate tense situations. Starting at 5th level, you can add your Wisdom modifier to {@skill Persuasion} checks.

In addition, at the end of a long rest, you can use your cook's utensils to prepare care packages for your allies. Care packages contain items such as tasty rations, sweets or thoughtful handouts intended to boost morale and fill stomachs. You can only create a maximum of five care packages at a time, and can only possess up to a maximum of five at once.

Care packages take five minutes to consume and enjoy. Upon completion, they grant an amount of temporary hit points equal to {@dice 1d6} + your Folk Hero level and provide nourishment for an entire day.
Alternatively, you can gift a care package to a creature not in your party. If accepted, you gain advantage on Charisma checks with that creature for the next hour.

subclassFeatures.name: Two-Fold Rest
entries: While the party is sleeping, that is when the innkeep's work truly begins. Starting at 9th level, while your allies are taking a short rest, you can choose to forgo taking a rest yourself and instead tend to their needs. This includes cooking, cleaning and otherwise making the campsite more hospitable. Doing so increases the effectiveness of a short rest for your allies.

Designate a campsite within a 60-foot radius. You become responsible for the upkeep of that campsite, and any friendly creature who sleeps within that radius regain double the amount of hit points rolling hit die.

In addition to hit die, allies resting within your campsite can choose to recover expended spell slots. The spell slots recovered have a total combined level that is equal to or less than a third of your Folk Hero level (rounded up, no higher than 6). An ally can choose to forgo recovering spell slots and instead choose to remove one point of {@condition exhaustion} instead.

At the completion of the short rest, you do not gain any benefits from your Two-Fold Rest, nor do you gain any benefits from taking a short rest. Once you use this feature, you cannot use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeatures.name: Wondrous Fare
entries: Starting at 14th level, your cooking is downright magical. At the conclusion of a long rest, you can use your cooking utensils to brew {@item potions of greater healing|PHB} equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1). Unlike other potions, yours require the freshest ingredients to function, and lose their effectiveness after 24 hours.
